title: Kill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair
notes: The Shaw brothers logo, the grind-house feature  presentation… this is Gahdamn exciting.. the Soundtrack and score slap So Hard!

title: Heroes Shed No Tears
notes: In the Korean Cut, The heroes do shed tears!...

title: Christmas Bloody Christmas
notes: It almost starts out as a hangout film. You dig these punk rock characters. You relate to the Conversations and topics debates on horror films, rock albums...

title: The Running Man
notes: It was alright…. I don’t like to be negative in any my reviews so… the positives.. Fast paced a ride, but I feel nothing was earned. It was too fast paced...

title: Black Christmas
notes: Pulpy, gory, Amusing. Not near the classic the original is. But at a brisk pace and in around under 90mins, this flew by! Well made! People under the stairs inspired, Halloweenesque,  slasher mishmash!. With a who’s who cast of the early 2000s. This stands on its own!

title: Time And Tide
notes: Very confusing. But stylish, Fantastic action but I’m baffled.!

title: Silent Night
notes: The return of John Woo to American movies.  On first watch when it came out, I thought it was good… But a friend of mine was right it gets better upon rewatches. It commits to its Premise and its gimmicks...

title: Djinn
notes: Tobe Hooper’s Final Film…

title: Behind The Mask: The Rise Of Leslie Vernon
notes: Solid Deconstruction of the genre horror entry. Great to see Robert Englund play a character again that isn’t evil. Fun winks and nods to horror.

title: Night Terrors
notes: This Movie is fucking bonkers. On the surface it seems bad, bad acting bad script, but For any hooper Fan, there’s lots to mine. A historical Exercise in sex cults, archaeology and Loss of innocence...

title: The Transporter
notes: This Movie is a vibe!…

title: Almost Heros
notes: Just A solid 90 min comedy. It’s a familiar 90s greatest hits of gags you’ve seen in other Films of that era. But done in its own way and still hilarious. Apparently this is Christopher Guest’s only Narrative non self aware style film...

title: The Killer
notes: Woo’s Reload is an elegant departure From his original, different enough… Not better But A serviceable Luc Besson style European actioner I say that with affection...

title: V For Vendetta
notes: Powerful, Moving, eye opening, relevant, entertaining. This film hit harder then ever before...

title: Punisher: War Zone
notes: If You squint You’ll see Steven Seagal is the punisher in this film. Does it make better ? Maybe...

title: The Punisher
notes: The first quarter Dark. The 2nd quarter sweet. The third quarter Fun.  All in all  lol still holds up. Actions is solid. Even if it rips off the Mad Max Family murder.

title: Prophecy
notes: This movie is shot really well, atmospheric  and is about important topics: corporate environmental pollution, human activism, Indigenous relations to logging companies...

title: King Kong
notes: A masterpiece. A grand adventure. Effects still hold up, a wonderful tribute to the original film while being worth and stands on its own merits...

title: Raw Deal
notes: They gave Schwarzenegger a raw deal… Nobody gives Schwarzenegger a Raw deal...

title: End Of Days
notes: In the top 5 Arnold Movies. One of his best performances. It falls into the age old adage is a hero is only as good as villain...

title: Phenomena
notes: Very atmospheric, creepy crawlies, A bit of a riff On Susperia. But Welcomed...

title: New Nightmare
notes: This film is very much about real Horrors. The fear of loosing your family. It’s amazing how...

title: Wishmaster
notes: Lots of great practical effects on display. Add in a late 90s Scream like atmosphere..

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street: The Dream Child
notes: While you get some great  sequences namely the uncut Motorbike taking over Alice’s boyfriend...

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master
notes: The Goldfinger of Freddy Films. In 4K!

title: Play Dirty
notes: Gahdamn I had high hopes for this. But the nice guys it is not. Not even close. But Enjoyable, opening credits were very James Bond style...

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors
notes: You know This series is not afraid to kill off its main and characters you care about! Something scream should have done a long time ago. Up the ante, up the stakes!

title: A Nightmare on Elm Street
notes: Wes Craven’s Masterpiece. The atmosphere, the creepin score, the performances The sheer brilliance of the very idea of a dream demon still hold up so strongly today...

title: Freddy’s Dead: The Final Nightmare
notes: You know what it’s fun. Not taken as a scary horror movie and more as a zainy tour de force. This movie is never boring at the least. And some great exciting visuals, good new Freddy lore and backstory at best. Add in some cameos that still hold up today. A fun revisit on glorious 4K! Like seed of chucky this deserves reappraisal for how fun it is, shaking up the formula and Bringing in a Jon Waters esque touch.

title: Return Of The Living Dead 3
notes: Solid Yuzna Joint. Special makeup effects by Steve Johnson. Solid love story at the centre, great original take/ shake up of the Dead Films and the return of the living films. Something a little different. Can’t take your eye off Melinda Clarke!

title: Dawn of the Dead
notes: Watched the Argento Cur for the first time… Still like Romero’s cut better. This is still a classic on repeat viewings.

title: Day of the Dead
notes: This movie is a masterstroke in existential dread, Hope, humanity. The effects are incredible Tom Savini’s best work. The score is fitting. This film, dare I say is better Than DAWN….But Just by a hair. Bub deserves to be in the Pantheon of misunderstood monsters like Karloff’s Frankenstein or Logosi’s Dracula. This film It’s its own thing and  feeling. I get caught up in the characters and their ideals.  Timeless, the future belongs to a band of outsiders. But do they make it out?.. 1985 is a huge year for horror, Re~animator, Fright Night, Lifeforce and This stands with The greats of that year or any year!

title: Fubar 2
notes: Better than the first! But the first is A Canadian phenomenon

title: Diary Of The Dead
notes: There’s some genuine good stuff in here. Romero quirky characters, social commentary etc. but it’s a bit of mix bag and an almagamation of ideas better presented in his other dead films. A bit of a departure from the rest. Not in the best of ways. Viewers will be rewarded if they can pick up on the voices in the media: Wes Craven, Tarantino, Del Toro.. This is what I end up taking away. lol. Oh well it’s been fun to revisit these latter Romero dead films. Land being the best and Survival being a close second. Glad  his send off film was survival of the dead. And not….

title: Survival Of The Dead
notes: The closest thing we will ever get to Romero’s Western…

title: The Crazies
notes: Solid remake, updated. But not better than the OG. Gone is the sharp satire. However enjoyable on a simple level. Good riff on the ending. Timothy Olyphant is a solid lead. Love the Opening song by Johnny Cash. Bookended by another solid song at the end.

title: Land of the Dead
notes: Solid! Still saying new things with a fun cast on they’re way north to Canada for a better life. Deeper felt zombies. A little slow to get going but a solid second half and ultimately a hopeful ending! Some great atmospheric Romero ! Still so relevant!

title: Billy Joel: And So It Goes
notes: Even if you’re the biggest fan, which I consider myself amongst them… You’ve  never ever seen or heard it sung or told before like this!... Beautiful , honest, close up.. A man for all seasons Mr Billy Joel..

title: The Dark Half
notes: Peak Romero!

title: The Crazies
notes: Bleak, relevant, horror in the daylight. Confusion panic and the attempt of the inept Government to control what is vague. what makes this so scary is it feels almost documentary there’s no style per say, it’s played out for you plain and simple. There’s no change in score or mood lighting to indicate the horrors. But oh so effective early works from the master George A Romero. I know when I revisit this I’ll find more to gain and shudder at. I’m glad I gave this one another chance. A zombie film it is not. But a good runner up to Dawn.

title: Jaws
notes: Saw this in theatres Today for the 50th anniversary. What can I say that hasn’t been said. Still a masterpiece! Saw things that I didn’t see before …and In glorious 4K!

title: Zombie Flesh Eaters
notes: The Italian zombie film Deemed to have saved the Italian film industry. Fulci’s magnum opus is a wonder to behold. This film almost has Bond like elements: exotic locations, globe trotting, Island Layers even a shark scene!. Its beauty is a juxtaposition to the horror on display. It pays homage to so many horror classics, Island of lost souls, Dracula, and of course Romero. But it blends spectacularly and Into a gothic flesh eating epic! I saw this film when I was in my teens working at blockbuster. It was at the beginning of my horror hound fandom adventure. This film blew my mind! And gotta say today it still holds up, in fact I was appreciative of the way it was shot! Not to mention a great score.  The scene stealing locations, literally Fulci did not have permission to shoot on the Brooklyn bridge and he used a tourist helicopter to grab those stunning opening shots of The harbour. Having this knowledge and seeing it as an adult just deepens my appreciation for this masterpiece.

title: 28 Years Later
notes: A beautiful film. A great experience in the cinema. A film about things, coming of age, rethinking nations, call to  adventure! The Patriarchy the matriarchy. A wild ride rifle and an emotional one. Looking forward to the best chapter.

title: Gung Ho
notes: This Is a real turning point for Keaton and Ron Howard’s career.. Keaton is real funny as he was known in the early 80s, but shows some real heft showing his actor chops with multiple Speeches from the podium before Pacino became known for rousing speeches. Ron Howard handling the comedy ala Night shift but just as well interested in the larger deeper story.. Balancing  the  Race relations of Japan and USA learning from each others cultures and Ultimately finding common ground set in the automobile Manufacturing industry.  It’s a heart warming drama and equally a hilarious comedy. Ahead of its time. A killer 80s soundtrack! Solid supporting turns from Mimi Rogers, John tuturro ,George Wendt,Gedde Watanabe. Keaton in top form! One of his best comedies of the 80s next to Beetlejuice. Would recommend! Facts: 1986 Filmed and takes place in Keaton’s native Pittsburgh Pennsylvania. Known as :Working class Man in Australia. Title song by : Jimmy Barnes

title: Freaky
notes: If you’re a fan of Vince Vaughn and Horror comedies, this is top shelf genre fare and gender bender body swap! It’s a lotta fun!

title: Maniac
notes: Fantastic remake! Very effective, stylized,ugly, retelling.  Scarily modern. The POV is masterful tool, not gimmicky. Haunting and uncomfortable. It’s very Silence of the lambs inspired and directly pulls the Goodbye horses, but you know you’re in for much creepiness when that song drops so it sets an expectation and delivers.  Better than long legs and A bit more palatable to watch Then Henry. It pulls from REFN as well, I’m surprised he’s not a producer. Same director and producer of P2 which I also enjoyed but this has more bite. I’m always curious to see Aja attached projects. As far as Modern horror goes look no further. If you can stomach it ;).

title: No Time To Die
notes: The 3rd best Bond film of Craig’s tenure. After Casino Royale & Quantum of Solace. This film worked for me the first 2 times I saw it in theatres and it’s aged well as the last of the Eon productions Bond. A real farewell to arms. Until James Bond returns…

title: Lethal Weapon
notes: Riggs empties his 2nd beretta clip on the helicopter disappearing behind the horizon. Murtaugh: through?. Riggs:  I haven’t even started..This Is the ultimate Buddy cop film. The summer watch you feel sunny LA. At Christmas you feel more that spirit, and the loneliness around the “silly season”. Having Recently watched the directors cut on 4K (which I haven’t seen since VHS and TV. I’d like to review that. At the beginning, you spend more time with the characters in their respective lives. Especially Riggs, the cutting back and fourth from Him to Murtaugh gives you more perspective on who these guys are before they are partnered up. What I love is in this cut it’s both of their movie! I have seen this film more times than I can count and I was hanging on every scene! The dialogue and colours popped. The score pitch perfect and some scenes linger a little longer. When Riggs leaves the Murtaugh residence for the first time. He picks up a hooker to just watch TV with him, it’s bittersweet. As he’s melancholy for the company he just had but he’s not so alone to go back to his place and put a gun to his head. This movie is a product of the 80’s with high octane action and the  buddy formula. But it’s oh so timeless cause of the relationship between the 2 characters and the chemistry between the two leads.  The scene in Murtaugh’s car after Riggs has jumped of the building; how they start to get along through humour and the absurdity of it all is really organic. Each scene is affected  by the  one before it. It’s endlessly rewatchable in every sense of the word.  Shane Black a young screenwriter 22 at the time. Bursting on to the scene with Dick Donner at the helm a director with clout knowing what he had in Black, stayed true to a lot of his script. Then add Joel Silver the big time producer who stills Produces Blacks Work Today (see The Nice Guys). This is one hell of a stew of talent that made an all time classic that spawned a great series! It’s one I’ll return to again and again. Christmas and summer!

title: Virtuosity
notes: You know what I used to think this was a bad film back in the 90s when I owned it on vhs. But I still loved it on an ironic level. But now Its oddly more prescient, then I could have imagined. Sure it’s an over the top performance from Russell Crowe and it’s far from Denzel’s best. But by jobe it’s so much fun! The action in it is great. The sound design is stellar; something about the bullet sfx just adds hella impact. It’s of mixture of Demoltion man, escape from New York, Terminator all while being a sci fi, horror, and a prison film! For a film with less money it seems to have landed a great cast even if they are just taking a pay check, such as the likes of Louise fletcher. It could be mindless but It’s stimulates to spot the things ahead of its time. Like the president threatening closing the borders to immigration, A villain obsessed with followers, and doing things for the camera with a viewership count ala a livestream..  just to name a few. The score is solid and some good needle drops by Peter Gabriel and the Beegees. This all almagamates into a hodge podge sci fi future Crystal ball product of the 90s Good time! For my money In terms of the Cyber punk entries of the 90s. I’llI take this over Johnny Menemonic any day, even if the B & W version is better. Happy I finally Own this on 4K (Vyn Syn) since my VHS is lost to time.

title: Tales from the Hood 3
notes: While Not the strongest or strangest in the series, I was pumped for this one cause the 2nd entry was so strong. However they opted out of the Mr Sims Crypt keeper Story teller. I was hoping Tony Todd Would be Stepping in with his own interpretation of that role. alas it was not to be. He is in the wraparound story, and I appreciated the new direction they went with.That was most likely  the highlight. The first story was the creepiest and strongest.The rest were middling to ok.  It may appreciate over time.  Tony Todd always great to see on screen !

title: Campfire Tales
director: Matt Cooper & Martin Kunert & David Semel
notes: A great little forgotten Anthology horror. It stands out from the pack, in utter creepiness. The wrap around story is solid as well! Fun Ron Livingston performance.

title: Evil Dead Rise
notes: Great sense of dread. Very Raimi inspired almost the unflinching no one is safe Ala Drag me to hell. At the same time it’s doing something new, new setting but stays true to evil dead canon of Horrors. You care about the characters and the shit they’re in.  Once the scares begin, and not a cheap scare in the lot, it never lets up! I wasn’t expecting the body horror Society inspired…really gruesome stuff. oh yeah and a scary banger of an opening!

title: Robot Jox
notes: Great effects. Giant robots, a precursor to Pacific Rim and Power rangers. Love me some Stuart Gordon.

title: Mission: Impossible – Rogue Nation
notes: In the top 3 of the series.

title: The Offence
notes: One of Connery best performances, and his best Sydney Lumet collaboration. Followed  by the hill. A Story of man a detective haunted by the the things he can’t unsee. The evil that men do.  His PTSD has caught up with him. This movie is very contained, very grounded and very realistic. Most of the films is made up of strong scenes almost as set pieces as it is based on a play. It unfolds through scenes of interrogation, but very one different and more grilling than the last. It’s steeped  in 70s cop genre grimness that Lumet does so well. This one dare I say is as good if not better then Serpico. However Pacino’s Serpico you can root for him standing up to the injustice. Connery’s Det  Johnson is a man coming apart from the inside out. It’s a tough watch but oh so engaging.

title: Robin Hood: Men in Tights
notes: I love Mel Brooks, and as a kid this was probably my favourite of his filmography. But As a I get older and have gone back and watched Blazing Saddles, that’s probably his best. However this film is An easy watch. Both as a Robin Hood film of its own and a comedy  spoof of the Costner film and The original Errol Flynn film. It’s Zainy goofy and light. The gags still hit, and a couple lines are lol knee slapper funny. While it sends up The source material, Brooks films have a respect and affection and can be firmly categorized in the genre they’re poking fun at. This is very much a Robin Hood film as Young Frankenstein and Dracula dead and loving are horror comedies Monster movies.

title: Mission: Impossible – The Final Reckoning
notes: Emotional. Great set pieces A fitting end to the series.
